text: A misleading article of social media suggests that Democrats at home want to give non-citizens the right to vote. "Hoss Demes 228 Yes 197 GOP not to allow illegal aliens the right to vote. Let that sink in America!" On March 9, he was mentioned on Facebook, which was posted on a page called Donald Trump for President Martin of Florida County. The text oversimplifies the voting in the United States House. This quote was referred to as part of Facebook's efforts to combat false news and misleading information in the broadcast of the news. ∙ (Read more about our partnership with Facebook.) As Snoops points out, there are other differences in the claim around it. Some conservative politicians and activists were alarmed about the vote of non-citizens, including President Donald Trump (often without evidence). There are cases of non-citizens voting, but they are statistically rare. Facebook does not provide any further details. With regard to human resources 1, the bill calls for comprehensive changes in voting rights and the financing of electoral campaigns. The draft law was approved by the Democratic-led House of Representatives on 8 March, but the majority leader of the Senate, Mitch McConnell, R.K., said that he did not intend to put the legislation to a vote. Read more: Does HR 1 expand voting rights or seize federal authority? The specific vote on Facebook was on a proposal before the final vote on the bill. The proposal made by the Republic, Dan Crenshaw, R-Texas, stated that "the feeling of Congress is that allowing illegal immigrants the right to vote reduces the value of voting rights and the power of voting for United States citizens." Crenshaw ' s proposal 228-197 was largely rejected according to party lines. The Facebook site was close to the margin of the vote, but it was over-magnified. There was one Republican who joined the Democrats against the Movement, and six Democrats who joined the Republicans in favour. By voting against a proposal to the effect that allowing illegal immigrants to vote reduces the value of the right to vote, it opened the door for conservatives to attack Democrats - although this claim is exaggerated by Facebook. Only because Democrats voted against a proposal that reaffirms that illegal immigrants cannot vote does not mean that they voted to allow them to vote. On January 18, 2021, in an interview with the right national radio program, "China was behind intervention and effort to overthrow our government and elections, electoral fraud." • January 19, 2012, there is a law in the United States prohibiting non-citizens from voting for the presidency or other federal positions. Human resources 1 does not change this law - human resources 1 does not call for the extension of the right to vote to non-citizens. The Crenshaw proposal acknowledged this point about the existing law, stating that "Federal law prohibits non-citizens from voting in elections for a federal office." Voting on "Congress Feeling" is a way for legislators to express an opinion, but it is not legally binding. This means that even if the Crenshaw movement were passed, it would only have symbolic force. The Republic of the United States, Zoe Lovegren, D-Calif., called for an attempt to shift from the mission "to extend voting rights to every American citizen in the federal election." While non-citizens cannot vote in federal elections, they can vote in some local elections in some jurisdictions. Crenshaw criticized such cities, including San Francisco, which allowed non-citizens to vote in school council elections, saying that they had been caught in "extremism" by expanding the right to vote for undocumented migrants. Crenshaw quoted: "Today I have put forward a proposal to reaffirm that only United States citizens should have the right to vote. Dems rejected it. Next time you go to the ballot box, put that in your mind. The future of their party is in cities like San Fran, where the illegitimate can vote. Let that sink in." Our Facebook article said 228 Democrats from the House of Representatives voted "to allow illegal aliens the right to vote." The text contains an inaccurate description of what was voted on. The article refers to a proposal sponsored by the Republic: "The feeling of Congress is that allowing illegal immigrants the right to vote reduces the value of the right to vote and reduces the voting power of United States citizens." The proposal cited only an example of allowing non-citizens to vote in local elections, while the Facebook text used frightening language to indicate that voting was of all kinds. The proposal was symbolic and would not have changed anything, because existing United States law already prohibits non-citizens from voting in federal elections. By voting against this measure, Democrats opened themselves to attacks - but simply did not move to allow non-citizens the right to vote.
